channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Slovenia Leaves the UN’s Big Tent
item.description: In this exclusive, wide-ranging video interview with PassBlue, Slovenian Ambassador Samuel Zbogar to the United Nations reflects on his country’s two-year term as an elected member of the Security Council amid some of the world’s most acute crises and raging wars. In this conversation, held at his office on Dec. 11, Zbogar, 63, delves into the Council’s recent visit to Syria and Lebanon, including the UN peacekeeping mission of UNIFIL; shares Slovenia’s views on talks to ending Russia's war in Ukraine; and opines on UN leadership, gender equality and the dynamics among big powers.

item.title: Devex Career Hub: The Trump effect, sector by sector
item.description: This week: the Trump effect on how development’s leading sectors are hiring; what we learned from a new survey of consultants post-USAID; featured new job leads; and more.

item.title: Countries adopt political declaration on diseases despite US pushback
item.description: The U.S. sought to stop the adoption of the declaration via a procedural vote, but the appeal failed to secure the majority vote required, with only three countries — Argentina, Israel and U.S. — supporting it.

item.title: Battle lines drawn in UK aid sector over sacking of Oxfam CEO
item.description: What happened to Halima Begum, formerly the head of the prominent NGO?

item.title: Devex Invested: DFC gets a long-awaited glow-up
item.description: The U.S. International Development Finance Corporation is set for a reauthorization. Plus, AGOA’s uneasy return, and a new push for multilateral bank alignment could point to a development finance system expanding fast — and operating under closer political control.

item.title: State Department scrambles to rebuild foreign aid workforce
item.description: “What we’re seeing anecdotally is a recreation of the things that we just tore down,” says Rohit Nepal, the Department of State vice president at the American Foreign Service Association.

item.title: India’s data-sharing model can help unlock credit for the ‘last billion’
item.description: Opinion: Building digital infrastructure isn’t enough — financial inclusion requires better data sharing. India’s Account Aggregator framework offers a blueprint for a secure, consent-driven way to onboard 1.3 billion people into the financial system.

item.title: Refugees Forced to Fill Gaps as Funding, Power and Legal Recognition Move Out of Reach
item.description: A new global synthesis report and refugee voices from East Africa and the Middle East warn that reductions in humanitarian footprints risks breaking the refugee protection system.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Billions of dollars in US aid trickle in from State
item.description: From July 23 to Dec.12, the State Department obligated $4.7 billion in new foreign aid to 22 countries. Plus, remembering food systems pioneer Nicholas Haan.

item.title: McGovern Foundation’s AI grants prioritize institutions over breakthroughs
item.description: The Patrick J. McGovern Foundation has announced more than $75 million in AI-related grants aimed at strengthening the institutions that shape how the technology is used.

item.title: UN rights chief warns of deepening repression in Venezuela, rising toll in Ukraine
item.description: The UN’s top human rights official warned on Tuesday that repression is tightening its grip in Venezuela while civilians in Ukraine face an ever-rising toll, as global attention drifts from two crises marked by deepening abuses and shrinking accountability.

item.title: New demolition order for West Bank camp is ‘more devastating news’
item.description: Israel has issued new demolition orders for the Nur Shams camp in the north of the occupied West Bank effective this week, which a senior official with the UN Palestine refugee agency (UNRWA) labelled as “more devastating news” for the region.

item.title: New influenza variant is surging, but vaccination still our best bet: WHO
item.description: Amid an early start to the Northern Hemisphere influenza season a new variant of the virus is rapidly gaining ground - but vaccination remains the “most effective defence”, the UN health agency said on Tuesday.

item.title: UN deal delivers a smoother ride for global trade
item.description: Moving goods around the world could soon become cheaper, faster and far more flexible, following the adoption of a new United Nations-backed agreement that modernises the paperwork behind global shipping.

item.title: Sudan: Intensifying hostilities bring new displacement, more casualties
item.description: The situation across Sudan’s Kordofan region is rapidly worsening, the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) warned on Monday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Landmark disease and mental health declaration, Afghan hunger deepens, DR Congo refugee crisis
item.description: World leaders meeting at the UN General Assembly have adopted a historic global declaration to tackle noncommunicable diseases and mental health conditions together, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced on Tuesday.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire still fragile as cold turns deadly, Security Council hears
item.description: The ceasefire in Gaza remains fragile, while humanitarians continue to face obstructions in delivering aid to the people, a senior UN official working to promote greater peace in the region told the Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Governments adopt UNEA-7 resolution on critical minerals and metals
item.description: The measure sets the stage for countries to adopt more environmentally sound means of managing minerals and metals such as lithium, cobalt, copper, and nickel amid rising demand.

item.title: Millions at Risk in 2026 as Aid Budgets Hit Historic Lows
item.description: 2025 has been an especially turbulent year for humanitarian aid operations as global aid budgets have experienced record declines in funding. As conflicts, environmental disasters, and economic crises intensify and disproportionately impact the world’s most vulnerable communities, the resources available in global emergency funds are falling far short of rapidly growing needs. For 2026, humanitarian […]

item.title: Asylum Seekers: Offshore, Off Course
item.description: The debate on reforming the European asylum system has gained significant momentum following the agreement reached by EU interior ministers last week. Alongside questions of solidarity and distribution, the possibility of establishing ‘return hubs’ outside the EU was at the heart of the meeting. Outsourcing asylum procedures – or at least those concerning rejected asylum […]

item.title: Trump Reboots US National Security Strategy, Foreign Policy
item.description: The new US National Security Strategy (NSS) repositions the superpower’s role in the world. Hence, foreign policy will be mainly driven by considerations of ‘making America great again’ (MAGA). Changing course The new NSS no longer presumes US world leadership and alliances based on values. It breaks with earlier post-Cold War foreign policy, upsetting those […]
